now I initially planned to utilize this

whether I could use this technique to

around 200 millivolts while rotating
which is way too low for the power bank

for charging so I disassembled the motor
once again and removed the old motor
face wires from the stayed on whose
winding specifications were three years
0.2 millimeter wires in parallel with 14
turns per stator pole nexts I started
thinking in theory we should get 10
times the voltage with 10 times
deterrence to try that out I used 0.1
millimeter enamel copper wire and for
starters that one on returns per state a
poll after completing one face with
their technique I temporarily
reassembled the motor to
see how much voltage it would output
this time and as expected the voltage
was a bit higher with peaks of around 1
volts which was a step in the right
direction but the big problem was that
this one face already featured
a resistance of around 27 ohms that
means that for example in a star
connection one current path would
feature a resistance of 54 ohms if you
would want to charge your battery before
point 2 volts and 100 milliamps you
would have a water drop of staggering
high 5 point 4 volts which means your
generator needs to create a total of
nine point six boots for that high of a
voltage though we would need way more
windings but because the space inside
the small stata is limited we would have
to use even thinner wire which once
again increases the resistance which on
the other hand means we need a higher
voltage this is an unsolvable vicious
circle but since I'm quite stubborn I
got myself to new ability motors this
time with initially lower kV ratings of
460 and 268 and even with those I was
never able to output sufficient voltage
and current at a lower rpm so all in all
small barely see motors cannot be used
but thankfully I got a decent motor
selection at hence my recommended picks
were those 3 o DC motors to which a

decrease the original high rpm of the
motor to lower rpm to test them I
measured the dimensions of their shafts
created a crude prototype crank in 1 2 3
D design 3d printed them and pushed them
in place
afterwards I connected the outputs of
the motors to my oscilloscope to see how
much voltage the output the first-born
were 400 rpm outputs for votes
the 200 rpm 1/5 olds and T 100 rpm 110
volts but of course that is not a
sufficient criterion for exclusion for
that I removed the electronics from my
power bank in order to find out where
could injects might generate a voltage
for charging first off though I added a
1n 4002 diodes and a 470 mukarat 35
volts capacitor to the motor outputs
like it shown here the diodes prevents
the motor from creating a reverse
voltage when cranked the wrong way
around and the capacitor smooths out the
generator voltage now my first idea was
adding a buck boost converter to the
generator outputs to create a stable 5
foot outputs and connecting that to the
inputs of the power bank circuits which
not coincidentally requires more or less
stable 5 volts but after practically
you're building up the circuits and
doing some testing I realized that the
output voltage of the buck boost
converter was not really stable which
led to the quick destruction of the
power bank circuits so my final solution
is much simpler by directly connecting
the smoothed out outputs of the
generator to the battery this way the
generator acts like a constant current
source and thus slowly increases the
voltage of the battery which is no
problem for the power bank circuits
since it is used to such voltage levels
you only have to be careful when the
battery is completely full because this
way you can easily overcharge it with
the generator which can lead to its
destruction and after doing a couple of
tests with the circuit setup and the
different generators I found out that
the 200 rpm one offers the most
comfortable but sturdy torque and
charges up the battery with up to 300
milliamps since the bad area features a
capacity of 2,000 million hours you
would have to crank around
seven hours for complete charge not very
practical when you think about it but
for an emergency situation definitely
usable so next my assistant created a
housing for the motor in 1 2 3 D design
in which after 3d printing its I secured
the motor with small screws afterwards I
used 2 component adhesive to secure and
xt60 a female connector in the housing
slits and once that was dry connected it
to the generator electronics and finally
closed the housing up with a couple of
m3 screws after I was then done
assembling the crank
we created a modified spec plates for

as he's up as well as soon as the glue
